reviews.review_title: Good except for the Nazi propaganda in the film
reviews.content: ***Contains spoilers***"Dead Poets Society" is a beloved film about an unorthodox teacher who struggles to free the hearts of his prep-school pupils. It is a touching, inspiring movie that I would have given a 10, if not for excess of Nazi propaganda. Only recently did I notice that there are no Jews, homosexuals, Slavic people, African-Americans, gypsies, or openly-homosexual characters in the movie. In fact, the society is one of racial purity and heteronormativity, and this is very troubling for anyone who cares about diversity. So what is the movie really about? It's about an Aryan uberman named John Keating who shows up to liberate a bunch of passive, girly boys from their headmaster overlord. He demands utter fealty, and tells his students they must be proud of who they are (i.e., caucasian and privileged). Even the arts and culture website The Dandy Goat has an interview about this, with both the screenwriter and Peter Weir, the director, saying the goal of the film was to give rise to a Fourth Reich.In the original script, Keating even shows up in a German WWII Panzer tank to destroy the school.Sheesh, so much for innocence in movies.

They want to be someone with emotion and sentiment. But, the reality does not flow into the way that they want. Even though the plot could easily have become terribly common, Robin Williams and other characters had the skill to make it gripping. The masterful acting kept my attention from beginning to end. Especially, the scene that students come together and listen to the poet, "O'me, O'life" by Walt Whitman, made me shiver. And the words "Carpe Diem" which means 'seize the day', remained in my brain after the movie. I'm wondering if I live like that. So, I really hope that such a movie will be released again in theaters.

reviews.review_title: Somewhere, Story like this still happens, So I hope that this movie would be seen by more people.
reviews.content: "Dead Poets Society" is a movie about students in Welton Academy, a conservative and traditional school, finding their own thoughts and ways of seeing the world, inspired by their new teacher, John keating. They form a club named "Dead Poets Society", and have poetry reading, and share free thoughts about their own view to the world, and try several things they are not allowed to even think about by school in a cave. They go through lots of changes in their perspective on their lives, but somehow, cruel reality of real society turns them down. However in the end they learn valuable lessons that they might never forget through their lives by "Standing Up" on their own feet. Through the movie, John Keating is always there to help the boys, and to instruct them to get to the real truth of life, "Carpe diem."Even though this movie is set in 1950s, I could easily empathize with the characters. Several settings in the movie such as their rigid instructor like Dr.Hager, suffocating father, Mr. Perry, or "Orthodox education method" that Dr.Hager insists, and mandatory school uniforms which kill the characteristics of each member of the students reminded me so much of my school life which was from 2005 to 2007. Because in Korea, still, fever of education for their kids among parents are irrationally rampant, I actually was kind of like the students in the movie who were forced by adults to "obey" the rules, never being allowed to "think" by themselves. Watching the movie, I felt the exact catharsis that those enthusiastic and ambitious boys felt with John's "unorthodox" way of teaching. Overall, the movie was so good that Iwould say it is one of my top best 10 movies from 20th century. The plot was very believable, and convincing, and the performances of the young actors were outstanding. I cried when they cried, and I shouted "Oh, captain, my captain!" when they shouted out loud "Oh, captain, my captain!" At the end, poignant scenes involving tears of sincere and poor boys left in the cruel society made me think a lot about "whose fault can we say it is on the tragedies." Could we blame the period of the time, 1950s, or generation, or just adults? I think it's "blindness" whether it is deliberate, or naturally passed that we have to think about. I think this question made it such a good movie. And because of so many parents in Korea these days still blindly pursuing only good results of school grades of their children, I think a movie like this should be seen more to be aware of what value we should put our priorities on – especially when it's about our society's future inner circle-to-be. Every year, I fear to use internet on the second week or the third week of November because it's when news about suicides of devastated Korean students who failed to succeed on College Scholastic Ability Test comes up on major portal sites. Whoever did not see this movie, especially if you are Korean, I highly recommend that you watch this movie.

Firstly, I'm not saying that anyone's opinion is wrong. Opinions can't be wrong, by their very nature. That said, it does seem as though a great many people take a very skewed lesson from this story.I'm not going to bother with rhetoric, I'm simply going to address the topic of the plot shift wherein Neil suicides. I've seen a great many posts from people saying that the lesson of Carpé Diem is completely undermined by the comedy-turned-tragedy moment of Neil's untimely death. Did anyone ever care to think that maybe the movie does not have the sole intention of imparting the wisdom of Carpé Diem to the young? Maybe the movie is much more well thought out than so many people seem to realize. Consider, for a moment, a new perspective. One where the minor character of Neil's Father is designed to get the attention of every overbearing, zealous, and controlling parent out there. Suddenly, the lessons of Carpé Diem and of following one's heart take a backseat to the lesson of "Live with your kin, not through them." Just because you've always dreamed that your son would be an astronaut doesn't mean that your son doesn't dream of being a fireman. Think about what happens to a moth when you capture it in your hands. A moth has what can best be described as a thin powder coating on its wings. If this powder is wiped off, the moth loses its ability to fly and very soon thereafter dies. Now, all the moth has to do to survive is stop attempting to fly away. But, nine times out of ten, that moth will keep beating its wings until the 'dust' has all been pulled from its wings and stuck to your palms, at which point the moth's fate is sealed. Just as our moth will die before it will give up flying, so will the man who hears his calling die before being sculpted by another's dreams. The square peg cannot fit the round hole.Now, think about how true-to-life this movie is. In the time of the story's setting, that was exactly how things worked. Even in modern times, this problem exists. Even if it's not as widespread or obvious.The entire movie revolves around Neil's desire to play "Puck" and shun the path to becoming a doctor in favour of answering his spirit's call to act. To those who think of this as offering the lesson of cowardice, please consider that it may not be cowardice so much as simply an inability to be anything other than what his spirit was drawn towards. If you need oxygen to live, and someone else ensures that you will not receive any: what is to become of you?Yes, there are a multitude of lessons contained in this multifaceted movie. Carpé Diem Stand for what you believe in Be Loyal etc... But the most important lesson can be summed into two words. "Be Tolerant." Be yourself, and allow others the same freedom. Just because you have the capability to control another is not to say that it is the right thing to do.To the Youth: Follow Your Heart. To the Aged: Raise your children, but raise them in their own image. To Everyone: Be Tolerant of other people's choices. If you don't like the choices of others, don't make the same ones for yourself.

Thought-provoking but oversimplified 

"Dead Poets Society" is definitely worth watching, but it loses a star due to two main points:

1 - Mr. Keating's encouragement for students to follow their dreams doesn't prepare them for the real-life consequences of choosing a less conservative path.

2 - The movie's portrayal of conservative authorities as heartless and irrational is an unfair oversimplification, as their emotions and reasons for advising against taking risks can be more complex.

The film's unrealistic nature stems from Mr. Keating being too left and other conservatives being too right. A more balanced approach would involve someone in the middle, tailoring their advice to each individual's personality and situation, such as strengthening Neil emotionally before encouraging him to pursue his dreams. A one-size-fits-all solution feels oversimplified.

Nevertheless, "Dead Poets Society" is a thought-provoking, well-directed, and well-produced movie that deserves 4 stars.

Dead Poets Society is a beautiful and heartbreaking film, especially in hindsight of circumstances around Robin Williams' tragic passing. This might be his best role ever - he balances his humor with infectious inspiration and realism. The film occasionally wavers with convincingly realistic dialogue and performances, but this is never the case for Williams, who brings every scene he's in right back down to Earth.

It's got some problematic moments, mostly surrounding the "relationship" between Knox and Chris, which varies from mildly creepy to outright predatory, and because of which Knox never suffers any consequences, of course. It would have been nice for a film with so much foresight and nuanced perspective to handle this topic a little more gracefully.

The rest of the subplots are generally really satisfying and the film does a good job of making relatively-low-stakes situations feel like life-or-death (up until the actual life-or-death situations show up, of course). The school administrators are written with a cold callousness that boils your blood and gets you emotionally-sided with our group of kids. And it was really refreshing to see all these kids actually look like kids, acne and all.

This is an extraordinary, flawed, beautiful film which I believe will only get better with age.

(a "carpe vita tua" ["seize your life"] film review by Timothy J. Verret)

Once again, God has the most impeccable timing of bringing me films to see at EXACTLY the impeccable timing God wants me to see them. This is the case in point of my watching of DEAD POETS SOCIETY. It's a film about "carpe diem" ("seize the day") but for me, the film elevates the viewer to "carpe vita tua" ("seize your life") while one still has all those "days to seize" of one's inevitably short life.

DEAD POETS SOCIETY is directed by Peter Weir (WITNESS [1985] and FEARLESS [1993]) and stars Robin Williams as a very unorthodox teacher, John Keating, in a very orthodox school, and features a cast of very talented young actors. The students have never been taught by anyone quite like Keating. The first day in Keating's class, Keating has every student rip out (actually, tear and shred) the pages of the introduction, "Understanding Poetry," to the book they will be studying. Keating in his unorthodox teaching proceeds to help each and every student find their own voice not only in poetry but also in their own lives. This is vital because there are three students highlighted in this film who need to find their voices. There is Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard) who wants to be an actor though his father wants him to be anything but an actor. There is Knox Overstreet (Josh Charles) who wants the most beautiful girl he ever saw to fall in love him even though she is way out of his league. And then there is Todd Anderson (Ethan Hawke) who is painfully shy and feels a deep sense of low self-worth (boy, can I identify with that!). It's Anderson, in particular, of great interest to me, because what Keating is able to teach Anderson is something Keating teaches all of us, i.e., "carpe vita tua" ("seize your life").

The late Robin Williams is who we all know (knew) and love (loved), and his performance in DEAD POETS SOCIETY is unlike anything Williams has (had) shown us before. The "manic" Williams is the "merciful" Keating in Williams' great performance in this film. John Keating teaches unorthodox methods that the faculty deem careless and irresponsible. What the faculty can't grasp is that the rigid rules and regulations they impose on their students is what will impose on their students conforming to rigid rules and regulations and, basically, their students becoming robots. But that's what the faculty wants, i.e., they want robots because then they won't be challenged when it comes to their rigid rules and regulations. In school or not, the world wants robots, too. Robots have no freedom to be who they are created by God to be. A school (or a world) that turns out robots at graduation is a school (or a world) that turns out robots to live robotic lives. Keating won't have that imposed on his students, and he goes to great lengths to ensure his students are exactly who God created them to be, i.e., precious and free. Keating probably wouldn't admit he's doing God's Work in DEAD POETS SOCIETY, but this is EXACTLY what Keating is doing, i.e., doing God's Work with his students to teach them, "do not conform to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God's will is—his good, pleasing and perfect will" (Romans 12:2). Keating is "good, pleasing, and perfect" to God for Keating is doing God's Will with God's Students.

Perry auditions for a play and gets the role of Puck in William Shakespeare's A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM. Sidebar: As an actor myself, I remember doing a Puck soliloquy in an acting class and because my elements are fire and wind, Puck's elements, one of the students in my class exclaimed, "Timothy, that's the best Puck I've ever seen!" Perry defies his father by playing free-spirited Puck and because of this, Perry's NOT free-spirited father tells Perry he will be leaving this orthodox school to go into another orthodox military academy. Perry can't accept the caged "orthodox life" that Keating taught him never to live, so Perry accepts the free "unorthodox death." Overstreet conforms not to this world and pursues his romantic interests toward the most beautiful girl he ever saw and in a very touching scene, when Overstreet is in the audience next to her watching Perry in his play and grabs for her hand and probably because of the spell the play casts, she's led to grasp Overstreet's hand right back. And then there is Anderson. Thank God director Weir understands that Anderson is his shining "pupil" in DEAD POETS SOCIETY. When Keating is let go from his teaching position, it is Anderson who makes the first move to not conform to this decision. One of Keating's teaching methods was to have each of his students stand on a desk so they could get a newer and better perspective on their lives from Up There. When Keating is leaving the class for the last time, it is Anderson who is the first one who stands up on his desk and says to Keating, "O Captain, my Captain" (from a poem by Walt Whitman, what Keating taught his students to call him). It is also Anderson who director Weir gives us as the final image of the film, so that we are left with, "Anderson, O Captain, my Captain, we see you up on that desk from where we are sitting, and we join you Up There!" Anderson is now "carpe diem" ("seize the day") when Keating leaves but, more importantly in that final image now and forever, Anderson is "carpe vita tua" ("seize your life").

With an Oscar-winning screenplay by Tom Schulman, DEAD POETS SOCIETY is a film where we are all invited to graduate, in school or not, to a higher plane in life and a higher life on a plane of "seizing your life." It is a film that invites us to be fearless, daring, courageous, to "not conform to this world but renew your mind." Robin Williams in an inspiring performance gives us John Keating who takes the minds and hearts of each of his students and gives them an "O Captain, my Captain" who they can follow to nonconformity, In doing so, we also can follow Keating, in school or not, to leave behind our robotic lives and discover what is God's "good, pleasing and perfect will," and this will is to "seize our lives" and NOT be held captive to any "O Captain, my Captain" who wants to teach us to conform.

"Rules were made to be broken." Indeed, they were! But we don't break rules just to break them. We break rules to be taught by God (and Keating) that we "break free" from conformity, because we won't be robots for anyone when we "seize your life."

I am a huge fan of Dead Poets Society ever since I first saw it a little more than three years ago. While the movie does wrap you up in a cozy blanket of boarding school shenanigans in a picturesque setting for the first one and a half hours only to rip out your heart and step on it during the last thirty minutes, it does so absolutely beautifully. The scenery is marvelous, the soundtrack is beautiful and the characters are engaging and relatable. Robin Williams' performance is, of course, an absolute highlight.

While it might have its schmaltzy moments, and contains the same message pretty much every big Robin Williams film contains, Dead Poets Society contains enough realistic writing and affecting performances to give it a life of its own. The late, great Williams, who was emotionally affected by a divorce he was going through at the time, is as likeable here as ever, and despite his limited screen time, he dominates the scenes he's in, and while his usually explosive comedic persona is noticeably reigned in here, he still gets most of the films funniest lines. His unique teaching style and reluctance to adhere to convention is what earns him the respect and adoration of his students, and while they question what he says throughout, they do grasp the central theme, and that's what makes his teaching so compelling. It's all about being an individual, and viewing poetry as a means of self-expression, not just regurgitating lines of dialogue and analysing them. Things slow down considerably in the 3rd act, but the final scene is an all-time classic, and once its over its hard not to have a smile on your face. It's a standout film in Robin William's oeuvre, and one that, as usual, he completely made his own.

This movie was particularly impactful for me as I watched it a week after becoming an English teacher at a high school for the first time. I was born on the year the movie was released, also I watched it with my little brother, who is a high school senior, and I watched it less than a week after a friend committed suicide, just days after a student told me she was having suicidal thoughts, with the added detail of Robin Williams' suicide tying a macabre bow on the whole experience for me. With all that being said, you would think that I could give it a higher score but the fact is it feels somewhat dated. I know it's set in 1959 but what I mean is the interactions between some of the characters just don't ring true for me, the boys act in over-the-top fashion over their love for poetry and for each other that at times it rings of falsity and performance. There are some good moments throughout however and the story is certainly quite moving, especially to me, at this particular point in my life, it truly hit a nerve. I'd been wanting to watch it for years, and it was well worth the wait to watch it right after my first week of English teaching. I actually ended up having one of my classes read an excerpt from Walden from their textbooks the very next day, the same one Mr.Keating uses to inspire his students to live deep and suck out all the marrow of life; To put to rout all that was not life; and not, when I had come to die, discover that I had not lived.

Oh, how I yearned for The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (1969) while watching this saccharine, trite film that portrays teachers as saintly figures without humanity rather than the complex figures they are in almost everyone's lives. I also had difficulty swallowing the film's thin credo when it was being doled out by Robin Williams who has always repelled me despite how beloved he is by some. Adding to my anger at the film was the knowledge that it earned the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay over the timeless Nora Ephron screenplay for When Harry Met Sally… (1989). This was not one of the best films of 1989, a fairly stacked year, as Enemies, A Love Story (1989), Say Anything… (1989) and Drugstore Cowboy (1989) were far more memorable and affecting.

Unconventional teacher John Keating, Robin Williams, disrupts the lives of his students at Welton Academy as he forces them to embrace poetry and do whatever they want because of the credos he pushes on them. The boys are negatively affected as Neil Perry, Robert Sean Leonard, decides to appear in a play against the wishes of his father Thomas, Kurtwood Smith, leading to disastrous consequences. He does allow the shy Todd Anderson, Ethan Hawke, to come out of his shell by embarrassing him and forcing him to make up a poem in front of his classmates. The other student in the group who receives their own subplot is Knox Overstreet, Josh Charles, who falls in love with blonde cheerleader Chris Noel, Alexandra Powers, despite her being in a committed relationship. In the end the boys stand up for the teacher who has brainwashed them with a symbolic gesture but he is still fired due to their actions.

Williams is so manic and intense in his performance while never quite convincing you that his character is genuine in his desire to educate these young men that it is difficult to follow him. We don't see what would inspire such devotion in this group of boys as they seem more like fevered cult members than diligent students. We are clearly meant to be charmed by the antics of the lead character but Williams is more annoying than hilarious or witty and we find ourselves turned off by his constant calls to action and attempts to turn these young men into radicals. I can't say the rest of the cast are of any particular note as Hawke and Leonard fill their roles nicely but don't stand out like Pamela Franklin or Lee Grant in far more original films. 

From there the rest of the film doesn't quite work as "Carpe diem" sounds less inspiring coming out of the mouth of a man who we are never really drawn to. The Tom Schulman screenplay doesn't help as it fails to be truly inspiring and instead inserts cheap platitudes in favor of scenes that would really explore youthful angst and the negative influence of a repressive society. The concerns of the boys also seem trivial while the film treats them as though they are paramount. If the film were to be made today Perry and Anderson would definitely be homosexual and while I understand why that would not have been a plot point in a mainstream film from 1989 I do think this would have been a more compelling struggle. The tragic event that punctuates the film was unearned and I felt horribly emotionally manipulated as the film portrays a confused teenager as a martyr for his beliefs. The only fascinating touch added to the scene is that Weir allows us to witness the devastated expression on Perry's father's face and just for a moment the film explore a difficult issue with some depth and perception.

It's unfortunate that many love this film and hold it up as being genuinely inspirational when it is so fake and manufactured. Peter Weir is a director capable of producing films with real emotional and dramatic heft such as The Truman Show (1998) and Fearless (1993) but his talents are no use when he is working with such a phony script and while the film may look good it has little to say. This is not one worth devoting over two hours of your time to.

The movie Dead Poets Society is about a new english teacher, Mr. Keating (Robin Williams) teaches his students unorthodox methods at an all boys preparatory school, Welton Academy, that is known for its high standards and traditions.  The boys at the school face some extreme pressures from the school and their own parents expectations.  Mr. Keating inspires the boys through these methods especially Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard), Todd Anderson (Ethan Hawke) and others to pursue their dreams, conquer their fears and seize the day.   This is supported by the storyline, characters, and the conflict, amongst the characters. 
Carpe Diem is demonstrated through the whole storyline of Dead Poets Society in several series of events.  The first scene where the boys of Welton Academy meet their new english teacher, was very crucial.  Mr. Keating told and expressed what poetry truly is and how the schools way of teaching it was wrong and demeaning.  He said,"I always thought the idea of education was to learn to think for yourself."  He wants to teach the boys to take advantage of their life and to seize the day.  He teaches the students to look at the world through a different point of view, with poetry and just in general.  He inspired the boys, and at the end of the movie, the boys especially Neil Perry and Todd Anderson, to accomplish their dreams and to conquer their fears.  Todd Anderson had severe anxiety speaking up in front of others.  When the Dead Poet's group was to be claimed as Mr. Keating's fault, Todd stood up.  Mr. Keating inspired the boys with "Carpe Diem" throughout the entire movie of Dead Poets Society.  
The characters in Dead Poets Society are pushed to conquer their daily challenges and the societies struggles through carpe diem.  Neil Perry yearns to become an actor but doesn't have enough courage to stand up to his father.  He once said, "I went to the woods because I wanted to live deliberately. I wanted to live deep and suck out all the marrow of life. To put to rout all that was not life; and not, when I had come to die, discover that I had not lived." He has realized that he wants to overcome his parents expectations and he wants to live life at its fullest.  Mr. Keating inspires Neil to face his family and to fulfill his dream instead of his parents dream for him.  Todd Anderson is a new student at Welton Academy and very introverted.  Neil helps Todd to get enough courage to stand up to himself.  Neil's suicide helps Todd push through it all and he was finally able to stand up to Mr. Nolan.  Todd said gets up on his desk and says,"Oh captain, my captain" which later the whole class joined him.  Mr. Keating, earlier in the movie taught the boys that poem and that was the first scene that truly inspired the boys about poetry.  Todd had extreme anxiety about speaking up, so when he stood up for Mr. Keating, he truly conquered his fear which was Mr. Keating's goal.  Both Neil and Todd struggled on a daily basis with their expectations and fears.  Mr. Keating taught them "Carpe Diem"- to seize the day- which led them to conquer their challenges. 
There are a couple of problems between the school, society, and relationships, that will be fixed with just the thought of seizing the day for the better.  At Welton Academy, the students are taught to obey authorities and internalize whatever knowledge their teachers pass on from older traditions.  Mr. Keating's way of teaching is to think for yourself and to seize the day.  His teaching methods are unusual compared to the standards of 1950's.  He gets the students to get up on their desk to look at the world at a different perspective.  He asks his students,"why do I stand up here?" He later answered with,"I stand upon my desk to remind myself that we must constantly look at things in a different way."  This truly inspires the boys to not only look at things differently such as poetry, but to conquer the high standards and traditions that the school forces upon the boys of Welton Academy.  The boys have conflicts with the school and also their parents.  Neil Perry is extremely intimidated by his father, who wants Neil to become a doctor.  Their biggest conflict is their lack of communication, Mr. Perry wanted what best for his son, and Neil wanted to find out who he was.  Their last fight they had Mr. Perry says,"I don't know why you insist on defying us."  Neil couldn't find the words to express his opinions with his father and Mr. Perry was unwilling to look at what his son wanted in life.  Dead Poets Society is filled with complications, and conflicts between the school and relationships.  Mr. Keating helps with all of these challenges by teaching the boys to seize the day.
On the other hand, some might say that Mr. Keating doesn't allow his students much original thought.  For example, Mr. Keating makes the students rip out pages in the book they're studying for because he doesn't believe in it.  That they were forced to learn the way he wanted them to learn.  However, he also had the boys get upon his desk and look at the world through a different point of view.  Everyone looks at things in different ways than the next, and Mr. Keating can't control that.  He wanted the boys to get their own opinion and original thought.  He doesn't want to control their lives anymore than what Welton Academy does.  Mr. Keating said,"You must strive to find your own voice because the longer you wait to begin, the less likely you are going to find it at all."  He wants the boys to strive, to pursue their dreams, to conquer their fears, and to seize the day.
Carpe Diem has helped the characters of Dead Poets Society to live in the moment, stand up for their beliefs and passions, and conquer their fears through many obstacles in their lives.  This movie inspired many people across the nation to seize the day for the greater good.  Mr. Keating didn't only change the boys lives but changed the tradition of the strict rules that the school forces upon the boys.  The conflicts in Dead Poets Society cause the boys some extreme stress and the lesson that Mr. Keating teaches about seizing the day and living in the present helped the boys handle the stress and conquer their fears.  Mr. Keating was a huge impact on the boys of Welton Academy, in the same way Robin Williams impacted the world with this role.

Dead Poets Society: "Seizing the Day" One Heartstring at a Time
Dead Poets Society will leave you feeling like you can seize more than just your day. If there had ever been a movie that urges you to feel every possible emotion, Dead Poets Society would be that film. Not only is it solemn and heartbreaking, it is witty and empowering.
	Set in the Northeast in the latter end of the 1950's, Dead Poets Society is about a group of students at an all-boys prep school, Welton Academy. Welton is an extremely elite and conservative academy with strict rules, leaving no room for nonsense. Any attempt at frivolity is squandered by stern parents or high-strung faculty. The lives of the group of students is altered when they meet their English professor, John Keating (Robin Williams). John Keating, an alumnus of Welton, is a poetry loving, independent thinking activist, who expands the minds of his students through his unorthodox teaching methods. Through those unorthodox teaching methods, Keating instills in the group of students the mindset of "carpe diem", or "seize the day". The "seize the day" mindset really comes into play in the students' lives when they revive an old school club that Keating founded during his time as a student, the Dead Poets Society. The Dead Poets Society is a group that meets to, "suck the marrow out of life" through poetry. Through the experiences that the group of students has with the freshly revived Dead Poets Society and their beloved professor John Keating, this group of formerly humdrum students begin to learn what it means to really live life.
	Major themes of the movie include independent thinking, benefits of non-conformity, and carpe diem (seize the day). All of the major themes of the movie are represented in a smaller way through certain teaching exercises of John Keating. For example, the theme of independent thinking is represented at the beginning of the new semester. He has the students tear out the introduction of their poetry textbook on the grounds that he believes the authors views on poetry are, "excrement." The theme of non-conformity is represented during one scene of the film when Keating takes the class outside to the courtyard. He has each student walk in their own unique way to demonstrate the point that everyone has their own way of doing things. When one of the students chooses to stand in place as opposed to walking with the rest of the class, Keating's response is, "thank you...you just illustrated the point. Swim against the stream." 
Dead Poets Society is reminiscent of other "inspiring teacher movies" such as Mr. Holland's Opus or Freedom Writers, in the way that in the beginning the authoritative figure isn't necessarily well received. The students don't necessarily connect with the teacher right in the beginning, but over time, the teacher is able to uplift and inspire those in their sphere of influence.
The director of Dead Poets Society, Peter Weir, could not have had a better compliment to the film than having Robin Williams. Robin Williams was absolutely magnificent as the English professor John Keating. Compared to other films that Robin Williams has acted in such as Good Will Hunting and Mrs. Doubtfire, he received relatively small amounts of screen time. However, the smaller amount of screen time did not hinder the film or his performance, it enhanced it. Even with Williams not eating up the screen time, he still managed to beautifully commandeer the film. Robin Williams made you feel as though John Keating was worthy enough to enroll yourself at Welton Academy just so you could find out for yourself what exactly it means to "seize the day."
	Dead Poets Society leaves you feeling as though there is much more to life than has previously met your eye. For those who feel they are in a stagnant rut of life, one of going through the motions and conforming to society, Dead Poets Society is the chicken soup for your soul. Upon finishing the movie, I feel like I have a lot of life in me to give. This movie will influence your thinking in a way that you will not want to just do life, but to actually live life.

A movie becomes iconic if it changes the way that you think and influences viewers to feel powerful emotions. Dead Poets Society undoubtedly succeeds in accomplishing these two things. Thousands of viewers over the past couple decades have been affected by the moving messages that are shared in this award-winning movie, but there are some elements of character and plot development that were not executed quite as well as they could have been. The promenade of pretty monologues greatly affect this movie in that they seek to mask these developmental errors.

This emblematic coming of age film takes place in a posh all-boys school in New England. Set in the late 1950's, Welton Academy is traditional and very serious until alumnus John Keating (Robin Williams)  is hired to be the new English professor. On the first day of class, Keating takes the students on a field trip to a display case and instills in their minds the urgency of "carpe diem". This initial scene includes an aforementioned pretty monologue' that rolls like liquid gold off of Mr. Keating's tongue and into the ears and hearts of student and audience member alike. This speech is excellently performed by Williams, however there is something about it that doesn't quite sit right. The creepy way that he whispers "carpe diem" and the fact that he has the boys lean uncomfortably close to the pictures reminds us how little we actually know about Keating's curious background as a former student at Welton. The mystery develops throughout the movie as the boys discover Mr. Keating's involvement with the original Dead Poets Society. Though this beginning monologue is powerful and will motivate you to seize the day, the wacky undertones allude to a cryptic past that begs to be explained, but is not made clear in the movie. 

The story continues with well-worded inspiring passages scattered throughout every other scene or so and the boys begin to adjust their lives to more fully seize the day. One student, Knox Overstreet (Josh Charles) becomes a hopeless romantic as he pursues a girl he hardly even knows, Chris. Knox takes many risks to try to woo Chris, including sneaking off of school property and riding his bike to town just to stare at her awkwardly from afar. This covetous behavior reaches its climax at a party, where drunken Knox "makes a move" on Chris and then gets punched several times by Chris' overprotective boyfriend Chet. Mr. Keating condones Knox's actions and tells the students that, "the purpose of language is to woo women." Knox proceeds to write a cheesy poem which he delivers to Chris and the entire scene is overdone and cliche. While a coming of age movie is not truly complete without a romance, the relationship between Knox and Chris could have been developed in a way that was more unique, and Knox's character development could have been more relatable.

Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard) decides to implement Mr. Keating's teachings by auditioning for a play, despite his father's disapproval. He gets the role as Puck in Midsummer Night's Dream which sparks an argument between him and his father and Neil goes to Mr. Keating to find guidance. Mr. Keating shares beautifully phrased counsel telling Neil that he should confront his father and tell him how passionate he is about acting. Neil attempts to communicate how he feels to his father, but is unsuccessful. This contention eventually leads to Mr. Perry threatening to take Neil out of Welton Academy and enroll him in a military school. Neil, feeling trapped, decides to commit suicide. After reviewing the events leading up to Neil's death it may seem plausible for him to take this course of action, however most audience members are left feeling confused at how the situation escalated so quickly. It seems like at one second the advice that Mr. Keating has given will mend the relationship between father and son, but then all of the sudden Neil is dead. As I have talked to other people about this movie, the most common observation I hear is that Neil's suicide doesn't make sense. If the movie had done a more thorough job of foreshadowing the death, or developing more grievous circumstances, perhaps this plot hole would not be as evident to audience members.

In its entirety, Dead Poets Society promotes an enhanced perspective on life that we all like to hear . It challenges us to seize the day and adopt a contemplative mindset. However the way this message is addressed could use some work. The monologues are wonderfully worded, but it seems that they only serve to masquerade over the fact that there are both character and plot development flaws in the movie. Unlike the poetry that these boys drool over, this movie is nothing but a people-pleasing prose parade.

I’m not typically a big fan of coming-of-age dramas, so trying to fathom why Dead Poets Society works so well for me is hard. A big part of it is that Robin Williams is so wonderful as the teacher who inspires these young men to live their lives to the fullest. I find myself so enthralled in the struggles of all these characters after his amazing speeches serve as an inciting incident. Then I just sit in awe as I watch how each boy is changed (or not changed) by the events in the film. There are so many scenes that I find impactful, and I could watch them completely independent of the rest of the movie and they would still give me chills or bring me to tears. If I were to make any complaint it would be a nitpick, but it would probably be that there seems to be a few scenes missing that could more effectively work through the arc of Ethan Hawke’s character. There are a few moments that don’t seem fully earned, because he’s not the most active player in the events of the film even though he is treated like a protagonist. I don’t notice it, though, because I find Dead Poets Society to be so thoroughly enjoyable in all other ways. I never would have thought that a movie so heavily focused on poetry would be one of my all-time favorites, but it is so powerful that I find myself wanting to read poems even though I hated that stuff when I was in school. It takes a special kind of movie to inspire an audience member to seek out things that he ordinarily dislikes.

I must admit, Dead Poets Society has been slightly ruined for me by the numerous parodies and references to it both on TV and in films over the years. I guess it's my own fault for not seeing it sooner. It hinges on a fantastic centralI must admit, Dead Poets Society has been slightly ruined for me by the numerous parodies and references to it both on TV and in films over the years. I guess it's my own fault for not seeing it sooner. It hinges on a fantastic central performance by Robin Williams, playing Mr. Keating, the physical embodiment of everyone's perfect teacher. He teaches a subject many would find dull, poetry, in unorthodox ways, not through reading from textbooks and note-taking, but through fun exercises and physical activity, and unlike the rest of the prep school teachers, he genuinely cares for his students. The cast of young actors playing Keating's students that re-form the titular Dead Poets Society that Keating founded in his youth, all do their part, but of particular note is Ethan Hawke's captivating break-out role as the painfully shy and troubled Todd Anderson. His characterisation results in one of the best scenes in the film, where Mr. Keating puts Todd on the spot and forces him to improvise a poem in front of his class, and through doing so, cures Todd of his crippling lack of confidence. The story does take a little while to get going, and the overall running time of the film feels a little gruelling, though the final act is superb. What surprised, and disappointed me the most about Dead Poets Society, considering how etched into popular culture it has become, is how little it actually had to say. There's only so far you can take the "seize the day" moral - Keating's students may be encouraged to have fun and enjoy life, but what happens when they all sit their exams, when they realise their teacher has taught them much about life, but not a whole lot they than actually apply to their studies? (Unless they plan to stand on their desk as a protest to archaic teaching methods for the rest of their education). It's a pleasant fantasy that you can get through school and university, and achieve your ambitions simply by living life to the full, but not a realistic one. Though if you're just looking for a pleasant bit of fantasy escapism with good performances, plenty of humour and heart, then look no further than Dead Poets Society. Though director Peter Weir has done far more intelligent, brilliant films since (The Truman Show, Master and Commander), it was this twee little comedy-drama that introduced him to the mainstream, and allowed his Hollywood career to blossom.

Bottom line: Dead Poet Society is a powerful and unique motivational movie that I will almost certainly see again. We open to an opening ceremony held in the chapel of a very old, very traditional, all male, prep school named Welton Academy. Led by a young man playing bagpipes, a line of boys walk to the front of the chapel. Four of them hold banners which state the four pillars of the school: tradition, honor, discipline, and excellence. This staunch tone is reflected in the students (and their parents) of the school. One student, Neil Perry (Leonard), has a domineering father who dictates the course for his son’s life; Neil will go to Welton, then to medical school, then become a doctor. A new English teacher, John Keating (Williams), was hired to replace the one who had retired. His methods are unorthodox. For one of the first few days of class, he has his students read an excerpt from the introduction of the official poetry textbook. It states that one might plot a graph whose x and y axis is meter and importance, respectively. The “greatness” of a poem can be defined by its placement on that graph. Keating vehemently opposes this notion and, in the spirit of rejection, he has his students tear it out of the book. They are dumbfounded but comply. Poetry isn’t something you can measure like a height and weight, Keating says, poetry is life. So to teach them about poetry, Keating is teaching them how to live and how to seize the day. His students, in each their own way, are touched by his teaching. Neil Perry, for example, comes to realize that he has always wanted to act and he works to make his dream a reality despite his father’s opposition. I thoroughly enjoyed Dead Poet Society. This is a motivational movie that hit the spot and departed from what I’ve always associated with motivational subject matter. That is, it wasn’t about an athlete persevering despite physical, emotional, or political obstacles. Not that there’s anything wrong with athletics but Dead Poet Society is refreshing. The use of poetry to develop the idea of living is lovely. It isn’t about them writing poetry, mind you, it is about the students breaking from their repressive molds by learning to appreciate poetry. Generally, I have mixed feelings about Robin Williams. Sometimes he can be a little much, but his performance as John Keating is fantastic. His antics are silly but not distracting. The acting overall is solid. It is really uplifting to see the students’ eyes light up as they develop a new outlook on life. I also really liked how the movie didn’t feel the need to give much if any epilogue. The students have a new perspective on life and that’s that. The movie doesn’t say “Student X went on to .” I really liked the music and the cinematography. There is a shot of a fall morning with flocks of birds taking off. The camera cuts over to flocks of students filling the stairwells of the academy on their way to class. Later, after a couple weeks of Keating’s teaching, one of the boys rides his bike down a hill through a flock of birds, disrupting them and causing them to fly. It is a simple yet effective visual metaphor. The only thing I didn’t really like is how, until obligatory sad portion, everything works out so perfectly. This isn’t anything major but I’ll describe why this is a pet peeve in my discussion post. Other than that, I had no issues with this movie. It got me pumped up and, I suppose, that’s the point of a motivational movie. I’d recommend this for any time, especially if you are feeling a little down.

The movie takes place in a conservative elite boarding school in Vermont and is about six boys who get inspired by their English teacher to take certain risks and develop their own character: Todd Anderson a shy boy who always feels inferiorThe movie takes place in a conservative elite boarding school in Vermont and is about six boys who get inspired by their English teacher to take certain risks and develop their own character: Todd Anderson a shy boy who always feels inferior to his older brother; Neill Perry  a very good student whose father forbids him any pleasure so he concentrates on school; Knox Overstreet the romantic one who is in love with an engaged girl; Richard Cameron a disloyal overachiever, Steven Meeks and Gerard Pitts best friends and mischievous Charlie Dalton often tries to escape from the “prison” of the boarding school by playing tricks on the headmaster. These boys will form the Dead Poets Society throughout the movie.The Welton Academy is a strict school, the lessons are hard and the boys do not have any chance to create individual thoughts . The new English teacher Mister Keating shows his students the beauty of poetry by giving unconventional lessons. His intention is to make them rethink their lives and what they want to achieve. He teaches them to feel poems and not to  analyse them in a theoretic mathematical way. As a tribute to Walt Whitman he wants to be called Oh Captain, my captain.When Neill finds out that Mister Keating was student of Welton and part of the Dead Poets Society. The teacher explains to his students that it was a group of boys who read poems together. The boys revive the Dead Poet Society and enjoy these moments when they cannot be caught smoking and laughing.Meanwhile, Neill begins to act A Midsummer Night’s Dream without his father’s permission. Knox goes to a party were he gets into trouble with Chris's boyfriend because he touched the hair of sleeping Chris. Todd is troubled with Mister Keating’s homework where they must write their own poem because he is too shy to perform it in front of the classroom. Keating helps him by inspiring him with a picture of Walt Whitman. Todd invents a poem spontaneously and the whole class is impressed.Few days before the opening performance Neill’s father finds out that his son acts without his permission and wants him to stop. Neill goes to Mister Keating who advises him to explain to his father that acting is what he loves to do. But Neill is too afraid of his father to tell him. Unfortunately, Neill’s father comes to the performance and sees his son on stage. Afterwards Neill is directly taken home where his parents tell him that he must join the Army and that he has to study medicine. When Neill tells them that this will take away ten years of his life and he does not want to do it, his father shouts at him and says that his son has to obey. In his despair Neill commits suicide while his parents are sleeping. The Dead Poet Society is a movie that shows the beauty of poetry, love and friendship. One can understand what the boys are feeling. These boys have always been confined between the walls of the boarding school and with parents who expect too much of them. They have no chance to form their personality. The boys have often tried to escape but the lessons of Mister Keating make them feel important as an individual with their feelings and thoughts. Keating shows them the advantages and problems concerning conformity.As Keating prefers the romantics, especially Walt Whitman, he has an optimistic view on the world and values passion. Mister Keating never tells the boys what they have to think. His only advice is: "Carpe diem. Seize the day, boys. Make your lives extraordinary." And this is what the boys are doing. The spectator can see how they start to enjoy lessons and question certain things even if others do not understand why. Knox risks everything when he meets Chris but he does it with passion and Neill loves acting. So they are living for themselves.And yes even if it’s shocking: Neill’s suicide is a very important element concerning this way of thinking. Because even though they are very optimistic in general they do not want to waste their life by living in a way they hate. When Neill’s parents tell him that he has to join the army, he realizes that he would never be free. After his studies his parents would have dicided about his career, which woman to marry etc. And from his point of view this is not "Sucking all the marrow out of life”,as Mister Keating quoted from Thoreau. Neill considered that this life was not worth living anymore. This movie shows the audience how poetry can touch and change people.As far as I am concerned, I started to value and admire poetry in a new way. Since I have watched this movie I have even begun to read poetry in my spare time and memorize quotes I like. The six boys are all very different so everybody has one to identify with. Then we can start to reflect upon our lives and if this is the way we want to live if it makes us happy. I'm convinced that everybody wants to be or do something extraordinary.This is definitely a movie everybody should have seen at least one time during his youth.
